comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Turning in formation high over the ocean. A3D-2 Skywarrior 138934 VAH-4 ' Fourunners' Modex 7. CVG-19 below NAVY Early type lightly framed canopy, rounded nosecone, periscope fairing beneath nose, gun turret and gun laying radar dome on rear fuselage. VAH-4 ' Fourunners' provided a detachment to Carrier Air Group Nineteen (CVG-19) on three occasions between 1960 & 1963 aboard CVA-31 USS Bon Homme Richard. Info from these 'GO!NAVY' webpages: www.gonavy.jp/CVG-CVG19f.html www.gonavy.jp/navy/sqn/VAQ131.html (Thanks and credit to Takafumi Hiroe of Japan for ‘GO!NAVY’ information) Color profile of above aircraft as depicted: wp.scn.ru/en/ww3/b/796/3/0/7 Unit: VAH-13, US Navy Serial: 7/ZB (BuNo.138934) www.aerofiles.com/_doug.html (use slider to scroll one third down page for second A3D entry and 138934) Picture of A3D-2 138934 being catapulted to take off speed, with tail code ZA of VAH-2, Modex 4. And from CVG-5 www.aerofiles.com/doug-a3d2.jpg 1958 picture of A3D-2 138934, tail code ZA of VAH-2, Modex 4. And from CVG-5 www015.upp.so-net.ne.jp/checkertail/archives/011.htm Passing overhead during landing at NAF Atsugi, Japan. VAH-2 Det B using code ZA was part of CVG-5 aboard CVA-31 USS BON HOMME RICHARD some time between July 12 & Dec.9, 1957 ('WestPac' voyage) www.gonavy.jp/CVG-CVG5f.html Picture of A3D-2 138934, tail code NG of CVG-9 landing at Yokota air base Japan. Date unknown: It may have belonged to VAH-2 on CVA-14 USS Ticonderoga 1957/1958 or with VAH-6 on CV-61 USS Ranger from 1960; www015.upp.so-net.ne.jp/checkertail/archives/060.htm www.gonavy.jp/navy/sqn/VAH06.html www.gonavy.jp/CVG-CVG9-2f.html Some notes on A-3B 138934; Originally built as A3D-2 Number 85 on Skywarrior production line Constructor Number 10795 Accepted by US Navy May 1957 Re-designated A-3B from 1962. March 4, 1963. Lost in carrier landing accident while operated by VAH-13. This dedicated 'A-3 Skywarrior Association' website records the incident: www.a3skywarrior.com/memorial/full_accident_date.htm A/C struck the ramp & boltered after going below the glide slope & LSO called wave off. MLG debris hit the LSO. Lost hydraulics preventing 'bingo' diversion to NAS Atsugi. Plane caught fire on the starboard beam. Two chutes were seen. A/C crashed 4 miles ahead of CVA [MLG; Main Landing Gear] The plane struck ramp while landing on CVA-63 USS Kitty Hawk, March 4, 1963 500 mi SE of Tokyo. Became airborne again, caught fire, 2 of three crewmembers seen parachuting from plane, plane crashed into ocean. 2 crewmembers killed, one survived. LSO hit by debris and injured. These facts confirmed by Kenneth Mortensen who was eyewitness of this accident. Pilot; Lieutenant Commander James Wilson Jr Bombardier Navigator; Lieutenant John Shoemaker AM3; ADJ2 Charles Eustace (AM3; Aircraft Structural Mechanic Third Class (Naval rating) (ADJ2; Aviation Machinist's Mate, Jet Engine Mechanic, Second Class [Navy rating]) Landing Signal Officer; LCDR William Carey It is not known who jumped out and if they survived, from the injury codes provided. (Thanks and credit to Takafumi Hiroe of Japan for all ‘GO!NAVY’ info) Go here for two very pertinent stories from men who experienced bailing out of a Skywarrior: www.a3skywarrior.com/whaletales/leaving.html 'We Are Leaving the Aircraft' and 'Crew Bails Out; Pilot Saves Plane'
